text: I think the biggest problem is people constantly pissing it out because their cells can't hold to it
uhm excuse me??? I'm an Udyr main.....

Might be surprising to people today but some oenologist extremists actually hold that you can never get a hangover from real wine and if you get a headache, heartburn, etc. after drinking a bottle of wine it means it certainly must have been adulterated or incorrectly prepared.

Like you see people saying wine makes their head hurt or gives them some other symptom and they will mention "sulfites" and according to French wine makers if you don't feel amazing after drinking wine it's either chemical additives or the grapes were harvested prematurely etc.
The French really don't play about their wines. The ComitÃ© RÃ©gional d'Action Viticole is just the surface...

The pizza paradox where if you put too much cheese on pizza it turns bad applies to beer too. You can try some craft stout with chocolatey coffee notes that's better than Guinness but if you had to drink it every day you would get sick of it. You would never get sick of Guinness.

It takes masterful craftsmanship to produce an industrial beverage product that's both very palatable, agreeable to the drinker and also whose taste isn't "too much" and that doesn't eventually make you nauseous and force you to consume it once a month or so at maximum. Balanced.
There's a threshold where the pizza starts to get soggy and loses its texture. Some have experienced it...

I sympathize with your struggle but also unless you are drinking very expensive wines from some specific regions of France whose production is also directly regulated by the French government this doesn't really apply to your case...
Endorsed.
19 year old me reading the Nassim Taleb "I wonder whether a bitter enemy would be jealous if he discovered that I hated someone else" aphorism for the first time
this is from The Bed of Procrustes
Expand on this please
T3

Any item or piece of clothing you see shown on Surivorman is something with deep personal lore for Les Stroud, e.g. the leather gloves he wears were made for him by a native woman he used to be friends with, the POV camerawork from the helicopter was by a random local kid he met.

Watching Survivorman you can intuit there is a lot of personal symbolism going on in the show. If you listen to Les Stroud's director's commentaries it's true, e.g. the jacket he wears in the airplane crash episode was something his mother had sewn for him out of woolen blankets.

It's just incredibly rich lore behind everything. He shouts an elementary school out because he kept an email address open where he would respond to all messages before the show got too big and they were among his early fans. So much of it was just improvised on spot and DIYed.

Then adds a footnote: "I need a qualifier here. There are exceptions, but there are also many known cases in which a prostitute falls in love with a client." The effect is striking. You read it and immediately see him as a grizzled Renaissance man with one foot in the Underworld.

One thing Taleb is brilliant at is adding these tiny footnotes and details in his texts that immediately make the reader see him as a wisened, street-smart and shrewd gentleman with rich experience in life. E.g. in one aphorism he compares Academia:knowledge::prostitution:love...

He's just so good at drawing you in with his mystique. It's one little line but you already imagine him as having been tangentially involved in the world of crime, no stranger to the bad part of town, having seen young fools fall in love with whores and the other way around, etc.
Congratulations brother, God bless
ðŸ˜ˆðŸ˜ˆ

Another Talebian aphoristic example: "When she shouts that what you did was unforgivable, she has already started to forgive you." You read this sentence and understand he's had a "past" as a womanizer, many turbulent relationships with beautiful lunatic women, wild affairs, etc.

Taleb is a master at self-mystification, The Bed of Procrustes is a hinted-at autobiography disguised as an aphorismic book. He shows wisdom on women's nature and simultaneously paints a picture of passionate arguments, screaming, making up, Monica Bellucci movies... It's genius.
It's a very short book, one afternoon read if you let them soak in your mind one by one
